bib.title: Fission induced in U-nat, Pb-nat, Au-197 and Ho-165by 80 and 100-MeV pi+ and pi-.

free_txt: Nuclear Physical Standards Laboratories.
Nuclear Physics Laboratory.
Last checking has been done.
The results have been compared with the scanty
data available on the subject and with systems having
comparable excitation energies.
Angular correlation of the reaction products have been
obtained.
Seven type of solid state nuclear track
detector, having different charge thresholds was used.
It is CR-39, CN-85, Makrofoil E, lexan, Muscovite mica,
Phosphate glass, Soda lime glass.
Careful selection of the detectors was made before
target deposition. Detectors not previously exposed to
the laboratory environment and having clean surfaces
were taken out of a stock of detectors reserved at
freezing temperatures. Muscovite mica detectors were
used after exposing freshly peeled-off layers. Mica
registers only the heavy products.
Track detectors of CR-39 registers both light and heavy
products.
The muon contamination of the pion beam is less than
20%. This contamination is not expected to contribute
more than 2% to the fission cross section when compared
to electrofission cross sections at the same momentum.
The fission contribution of an electron component
present in the beam is estimated to be less than 2%.
The contribution due to the proton contamination was
eliminated altogether by using an absorber in the beam
of pions. The contribution of these neutrons in the
U-natural fission cross section has been estimated to
be less than 3%. These contributions of slow and fast
neutrons were confirmed by Bonner sphere measurements
and the fission rate measurements when the target
detector assemblies were displaced away from the pion
beam.
Target layers of spectroscopically pure natural
uranium, lead, gold and holmium were deposited on the
selected detectors. The target thickness deposited
varied from about 300-mum/cm**2 to about 1.15 mg/cm**2,
as determined by weighing before and after deposition.
These thickness are known to 7% or better.
It is the statistical accuracy only.
Other sources of uncertainty in magnitude, as
already discussed, have been estimated to be about 20%.
It is the statistical accuracy only.

-By authors. 1. The 4-pi geometry detector arrangements
were analyzed to determine the differential angular
cross section distributions for the emission of light
products and the heavy fission fragments.
2. Fission fragment distribution have been normalized a
relative value of 2.5 for angular interval of 0-10
degrees for the target.
The angular distributions of the fission fragments and
of the light reaction products in different angular
intervals have been plotted relative to this normalized
value.
The uncertainty is shown on figures, without
any analysis.
By CAJAD.
